A **loadstone** is a type of [gem](/wiki/Gem "Gem") that appears in *[Nethack](/wiki/Nethack "Nethack")*. It is one of the four kinds of [gray stones](/wiki/Gray_stone "Gray stone"), and is the least desirable of them by far.

[ ]

## Contents

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

## Generation

Normally-generated loadstones on the dungeon's floor are always generated [cursed](/wiki/Cursed "Cursed"). 10⁄11 of loadstones inside [containers](/wiki/Container "Container") are generated as cursed, and the remainder are generated as non-cursed.

Player monsters on the [Astral Plane](/wiki/Astral_Plane "Astral Plane") have a 1⁄30 chance of being generated with a loadstone.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)

## Description

A loadstone weighs slightly more than an [iron ball](/wiki/Iron_ball "Iron ball") at 500 [aum](/wiki/Aum "Aum"), and ultimately serves as a "gotcha" item for the unwary: if the [hero](/wiki/Hero "Hero") pick a cursed loadstone up, they cannot [drop](/wiki/Drop "Drop") it or place it into a [container](/wiki/Container "Container"). Settings for the `pickup_burden` option will be ignored if the character attempts to pick up a loadstone, and other inventory restrictions may be ignored as well: if a character's [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory") has already reached the 52-item limit, the loadstone will still be picked up and assigned [#](/wiki/Hash_mark "Hash mark") as the inventory position. A loadstone will [autocurse](/wiki/Autocurse "Autocurse") once it is dropped or leaves the main [inventory](/wiki/Inventory "Inventory") in any other way.

Despite its weight, a loadstone does not deal any more damage than a [flint stone](/wiki/Flint_stone "Flint stone") when [thrown](/wiki/Thrown "Thrown"), including shooting from a [sling](/wiki/Sling "Sling").

## Strategy

Loadstones severely hinder the hero's movement and often renders them [stressed](/wiki/Stressed "Stressed") or worse, which will prevent them from goin up [stairways](/wiki/Stairway "Stairway"). There are several methods to dispose of a cursed loadstone:

- [Uncurse](/wiki/Curse_removal "Curse removal") the stone, then drop it.

  - Read a noncursed [scroll of remove curse](/wiki/Scroll_of_remove_curse "Scroll of remove curse"), or dip it into a [potion of holy water](/wiki/Potion_of_holy_water "Potion of holy water").
  - A successful [prayer](/wiki/Prayer "Prayer") can uncurse a loadstone, since having a cursed one counts as a [minor trouble](/wiki/Minor_trouble "Minor trouble").

- The hero can drop or stash all [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral") objects that they want to preserve, then cast [stone to flesh](/wiki/Spellbook_of_stone_to_flesh "Spellbook of stone to flesh") at themselves to turn the loadstone into a harmless [meatball](/wiki/Meatball "Meatball").

- Similarly, they can drop *all* objects that the do not want [cancelled](/wiki/Cancelled "Cancelled"), then either [zap](/wiki/Zap "Zap") a [wand of cancellation](/wiki/Wand_of_cancellation "Wand of cancellation") or cast the [cancellation](/wiki/Spellbook_of_cancellation "Spellbook of cancellation") spell at themselves.

- Dip the stone in a [potion of polymorph](/wiki/Potion_of_polymorph "Potion of polymorph") to transform it.

- Have a monster such as a [nymph](/wiki/Nymph "Nymph") steal it—this is very unreliable unless the hero can *safely* ensure no other desirable inventory is targeted.

Be careful not to throw a loadstone if you have [autopickup](/wiki/Autopickup "Autopickup") on!

### Testing for loadstones

Naturally, one of the most effective methods for dealing with loadstones is learning how to avoid them in the first place.

The easiest way to test if a gray stone is a loadstone is to [kick](/wiki/Kick "Kick") it *before* picking it up - loadstones are heavy enough that they cannot be kicked under normal circumstances. In the most "ideal" form of this test, the hero kicks the loadstone without enhanced strength (e.g. from [gauntlets of power](/wiki/Gauntlets_of_power "Gauntlets of power")) while it is on a non-[ice](/wiki/Ice "Ice") square, and there hero is in a [role](/wiki/Role "Role") that does not use [martial arts](/wiki/Martial_arts "Martial arts") (i.e. [Monk](/wiki/Monk "Monk") or [Samurai](/wiki/Samurai "Samurai")), and is not a form with a kicking bonus (i.e. a [sasquatch](/wiki/Sasquatch "Sasquatch")).[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) A Monk, Samurai, or a hero in the form of a sasquatch can still test for loadstones with this method: a loadstone will travel a much shorter distance than a harmless gray stone or any non-[fragile](/wiki/Fragile "Fragile") object of similar weight, like a [rock](/wiki/Rock "Rock")—be careful, as some kicking bonuses will add a small random amount to the distance.

As a mass majority of loadstones are generated cursed, heroes can also pet-test a suspected loadstone since they will only "reluctantly" move over it. This method also works on stones stuck next to undiggable walls, which occurs most often in [Mines' End](/wiki/Mines%27_End "Mines' End") - but beware of [level teleporter](/wiki/Level_teleporter "Level teleporter") traps. Loadstones also only autocurse when they are dropped or leave the inventory, so a hero can cancel a suspicious gray stone and pick it up; cancellation has no effect on gray stones beyond rendering them uncursed, and the hero can simply drop it if the stone turns out to be a loadstone.

Picking up a container with a loadstone inside will not cause it to stick in the hero's inventory: a `pickup_burden` that warns about severe encumbrance when lifting a container with a gray stone inside is *usually* a sign that the stone is a loadstone, though [large boxes](/wiki/Large_box "Large box") and [chests](/wiki/Chests "Chests") tend to be fairly heavy even when empty. A hero can also #[tip](/wiki/Tip "Tip") the container after removing all other items from it, then test the gray stone using the other above methods.

After determining that a gray stone is a loadstone, it should be type-[named](/wiki/Named "Named") or formally [identified](/wiki/Identification "Identification") it so that the hero can recognize any future ones. A hero reading a noncursed [scroll of remove curse](/wiki/Scroll_of_remove_curse "Scroll of remove curse") for other reasons may deliberately pick up a known loadstone. Beware sources of [amnesia](/wiki/Amnesia "Amnesia"), since the hero may forget the loadstone's identity!

## History

The loadstone is introduced in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0").

## Origin

The loadstone is one of the many "treasures" derived from *[Dungeons & Dragons](/wiki/Dungeons_%26_Dragons "Dungeons & Dragons")*, where it first appears in the 1st Edition *Dungeon Masters Guide*; it is also known as a "stone of weight". "Loadstone" is a pun on the word [lodestone](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/lodestone "wikipedia:lodestone"), a naturally magnetic mineral (which also alludes to its "sticky" properties).

A stone of weight causes a 50% reduction in attack and movement rate as soon as its owner has to move quickly in order to avoid an enemy; it also "sticks" to its owner and will always turn up on their person, no matter how they attempt to get rid of it. The stone can only be removed by casting "dispel evil", which causes it to permanently vanish. The loadstone of *NetHack* behaves in a similar spirit: it "sticks" to the holder's inventory and inconveniences them by slowing them down with its innate weight; curse removal is similarly required, though it does not destroy the stone, but makes it possible to drop or otherwise get rid of it.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), dipping a loadstone in a [potion of amnesia](/wiki/Potion_of_amnesia "Potion of amnesia") will transform it into a flint stone. This allows a hero to not only get rid of one, but uncurse and then [upgrade](/wiki/Upgrade "Upgrade") the resulting flint into a [healthstone](/wiki/Healthstone "Healthstone").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), a loadstone appears on the square south of the up [stair](/wiki/Stair "Stair") in [Asmodeus' Lair](/wiki/Asmodeus%27_Lair_\(UnNetHack\) "Asmodeus' Lair (UnNetHack)").

### Vulture

When using [Vulture](/wiki/Vulture "Vulture"), you can see the weight of items, so it is much easier to avoid picking up a loadstone. Drop a junk item on any suspect gray stone: this forces the pickup menu to appear since there are now several items. Gray stones weighing only 10 are harmless to pick up.

### dNetHack

In [dNetHack](/wiki/DNetHack "DNetHack"), [Center of All](/wiki/Center_of_All "Center of All") has a special projectile attack that launches a loadstone at the target; these thrown loadstones deal 1d30 damage and have a 1⁄3 chance of adding themselves to the target's inventory instead of dropping to the floor, which can quickly weigh down and immobilize targets. Loadstones generated this way are always cursed.

### xNetHack

[xNetHack](/wiki/XNetHack "XNetHack") removes the loadstone.

### SpliceHack

In [SpliceHack](/wiki/SpliceHack "SpliceHack"), a loadstone appears on the square south of the up [stair](/wiki/Stair "Stair") in [Asmodeus' Lair](/wiki/Asmodeus%27_Lair_\(SpliceHack\) "Asmodeus' Lair (SpliceHack)"), as in UnNetHack.

A loadstone can be combined with a [scroll of identify](/wiki/Scroll_of_identify "Scroll of identify") at a [furnace](/wiki/Furnace "Furnace") to create a [crystal ball](/wiki/Crystal_ball "Crystal ball").

### notdNetHack

In [notdNetHack](/wiki/NotdNetHack "NotdNetHack") and [notnotdNetHack](/wiki/NotnotdNetHack "NotnotdNetHack"), in addition to dNetHack details, loadstones can be made into [spearheads](/index.php?title=Spearhead\&action=edit\&redlink=1 "Spearhead (page does not exist)") that add +2d4 damage and make the spear [weldproof](/wiki/Weldproof "Weldproof").

### SlashTHEM

In [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM"), in addition to SLASH'EM details, [lithivores](/wiki/Lithivore "Lithivore") such as [rock moles](/wiki/Rock_mole "Rock mole") can eat loadstones—A hero can polymorph into a lithivorous monster to eat away a loadstone that they have picked up.

## Reference

2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/dokick.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 7](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/dokick.c#L7)

Loadstones generated this way are always cursed. ===xNetHack=== [[xNetHack]] removes the loadstone. ===SpliceHack=== In [[SpliceHack]], a loadstone appears on the square south of the up [[stair]] in [[Asmodeus' Lair (SpliceHack)|Asmodeus' Lair]], as in UnNetHack. A loadstone can be combined with a [[scroll of identify]] at a [[furnace]] to create a [[crystal ball]]. ===notdNetHack=== In [[notdNetHack]] and [[notnotdNetHack]], in addition to dNetHack details, loadstones can be made into [[spearhead]]s that add +2d4 damage and make the spear [[weldproof]]. ===SlashTHEM=== In [[SlashTHEM]], in addition to SLASH'EM details, [[lithivore]]s such as [[rock mole]]s can eat loadstones—A hero can polymorph into a lithivorous monster to eat away a loadstone that they have picked up. ==Reference== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Gems]]
